description:
In Surinam, as of the 16th of March, all schools will be closed. Initially, until the 14th of April but they just announced it will be longer. 

*Update* As of the 6th of July, schools in the west can reopen for the examination year (only 12 children are allowed per class). Schools in the East remain closed due to lockdown UPDATE: As of 6th July, Schools in most of the country have reopened for the examination year, however schools in the East, and in the villages remain closed.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: In Suriname, as of March 29th the Government of Suriname will institute a nationwide curfew for all residents with few exceptions from 8:00pm to 6:00am the next day, excluding people who work in healthcare, safety and essential destination traffic UPDATE: The original compliance of the policy was coded as Mandatory with exceptions, now the chief of Police has announced that they will lock people, who are on the streets during curfew hours, up for max. 24 hours.

description: In Suriname, "as of March 29th tot the 10th of May, the Government of Suriname instituted a nationwide curfew/partial-lockdown for all residents with a few exceptions (excluding people who work in healthcare, safety and essential destination traffic) from 8:00pm to 6:00am the next day. On May 9 it was announced that from the 10th of May, there will be a curfew from 11:00pm to 05:00am the next day". description:

 UPDATE: It was announced that the COVID-19 Crisis Management Team will come together as a formal task force from April 24, as part of the recently adopted COVID Exceptional Condition Act. The Exceptional Condition Act lasts until July 7.

description:

description: In Suriname, the Ministry of Finance starts from the May 18 with payment of social support from the COVID-19 Emergency Fund. This fund is for people who have a reduced or no income as a result of the COVID-19 crisis. The fund is intended to alleviate the acute distress of the least wealthy and groups hardest hit by the COVID-19 crisis.

description: In Suriname, from April 30 to May 10, through the whole country there will be more controle from the Police and the National Army
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: They want to more police and military on the street to make sure that everybody follows the rules that the government set up to prevent the spread of covid 19. So the government, together with the national military and the police, decided to put more controlling forces on the street.
